content: Hi Shep, Welcome! Ya came to the right place re. "Foot Problems" I seem to have more than my share, I have flat feet, due to that I have "Plantar Fasciitis" It can be painful, I need a special othotic for it. I have nail fungus, no real treatment except a pill, but Im' taking so many meds now, I don't need anymore. There is one thing I do, it's a self treatment, it's taking a long time, but so does the Rx...I wont mention it here, because you have to be careful. I don't want someone to try it and get hurt. I have bunions on both feet. I guess that pretty much covers it, I get grumpy a lot so you'll know, when I get mean, which is often. Don't take it personally! This message has been edited. Last edited by: Bergy46, Sun 12 April 2009 07:14 PM Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: quote: Originally posted by TJShep: Am I alone? I'm only 30 but my feet are killing me. Any advice. Shoes that don't crowd your feet might help, but best bet in a foot doctor that knows what he's talking about - - The regime there is anti-inflammatories then maybe surgery if that doesn't shrink 'em down and ease the pain - - On top of everything else, Mystical has bunions too - Good luck - - Wandering and Wondering

title: Any other guys deal with embarrasing feet problems....like bunions? corns?

content: Thanks Mikey, I went to a podiatrist, He's the one who diagnosed me. He had the special othotic made for me. I've had foot problems for most of my life, the Navy rejected me because of my feet. I did some wheeling and dealing and got them to waive my condition! He didn't say anything about Peripheral Neuropathy. I know what PN is our oldest granddaughter has it. That poor child, she is the one who had thyroid cancer. She seems to be doing better, she goes in for treatments about once a month! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: They had a documentary on one of the morning shows about nail fungus, and they said the pills work, but they take a month or two. They showed a new laser process where they shoot a laser through the nail, much the way they remove tattoos. The laser killed the fungus instantly, and the nail showed normal growth within a week or two . .. . Looked like a good idea - - Now here is a question: Most of you guys have smashed a finger or thumb or toe and had the nail turn purple and hurt like hell - and what do you do to relieve the pain?? You drill a hole in it and let the blood out, right?? And it feels better immediately, right?? So with nail fungus, why don't they drill a little hole or series of holes and drip some anti-fungus stuff right in there?? Wouldn't hurt that much, and the stuff would start dying immediately, just like the laser thing?? HMmmmmmm!! Wandering and Wondering
reply: They had a documentary on one of the morning shows about nail fungus, and they said the pills work, but they take a month or two. They showed a new laser process where they shoot a laser through the nail, much the way they remove tattoos. The laser killed the fungus instantly, and the nail showed normal growth within a week or two . .. . Looked like a good idea - - Now here is a question: Most of you guys have smashed a finger or thumb or toe and had the nail turn purple and hurt like hell - and what do you do to relieve the pain?? You drill a hole in it and let the blood out, right?? And it feels better immediately, right?? So with nail fungus, why don't they drill a little hole or series of holes and drip some anti-fungus stuff right in there?? Wouldn't hurt that much, and the stuff would start dying immediately, just like the laser thing?? HMmmmmmm!! Wandering and Wondering
title: Any other guys deal with embarrasing feet problems....like bunions? corns?

content: I wore BAD shoes (converse Chucks were my faves) in my misspent yute, and ended up w/ bunions on both feet. At age 35 I saw a podiatrist, who said although they qualified for operation(s), I should try a GOOD orthotic. Not those crappy foam ones they sell at the Walgreens, but a serious one w/ real support. It actually STOPPED the divergent action that had been going on for 5-10 years. 15 yrs later I went to him for the toe fungus. This is SERIOUS stuff -- they make you get bloodwork before and during the taking of the med to insure that you don't get liver damage (a potential side effect). It cleaned them up to a (relatively) pristine condition, and for the last five years I've been using Lotrimin sporadically to keep it in check. I also scrub those dogs vigorously with a serious brush and some hexachloaphine-based soap (Dial, Safeguard , etc). No more fungi, no yellow tonails, NO RELAPSES. Five years later I get laid off and decide to have the bunion surgery while I still had the COBRA mojo working for me. I am now 12 days post op and I have NO PAIN. I'm on crutches and it's going well. Since I can't bear any weight on the foot, having decent uppper body strength is a must. I had heard horror stories about the surgery -- bad pain, improper healing. But I ccouldn't walk long distances and when I'd get caught off-balance, I'd tweek the foot in ways that hurt for days. I wanted to be able to get back in running shape and get my health in order for retirement. I am 55 and in good shape. I think the older and worser in shape you get, the more poorly you'll respond to the surgery. Try a good orthotic (SPENCO) -- see if it helps; maybe you can put off the surgery till later.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Thanks Mikey, I went to a podiatrist, He's the one who diagnosed me. He had the special othotic made for me. I recently had some inserts made for my shoes. OP, so you know what we are talking about, the Dr. has you step into a styrofoam (or something like that) filled box so he can get an exact impression of your foot/feet. Then they will make shoe inserts that fit your feet, not just a generic cut. They do help me. My feet were crushed five years ago under the wheel of a Black Hawk helicopter. DUH!!! Don

title: Any other guys deal with embarrasing feet problems....like bunions? corns?

content: Toenail fungus problems are apparently the bane of the elderly. My mom's feet were a mess (she's 89). When we took her to a podiatrist, she refused to touch her (lazy POS). So I started cutting her toenails myself, and believe me, in the beginning, it was a sacrificial act of love. It's like clearing away dead wood from a tree so the live wood can grow. I had the bright idea of painting her toenails, thinking maybe it would smother the fungus. (Guess if a guy wanted to do that, he could use clear nail polish?) Anyway, it made them look better on a temporary basis, and made her feel better about herself. I've also started to really wash her feel well, with a very soapy washcloth. I am seeing a big improvement. She couldn't take the pills the docs gave her.

It cleaned them up to a (relatively) pristine condition, and for the last five years I've been using Lotrimin sporadically to keep it in check. I also scrub those dogs vigorously with a serious brush and some hexachloaphine-based soap (Dial, Safeguard , etc). No more fungi, no yellow tonails, NO RELAPSES. Five years later I get laid off and decide to have the bunion surgery while I still had the COBRA mojo working for me. I am now 12 days post op and I have NO PAIN. I'm on crutches and it's going well. Since I can't bear any weight on the foot, having decent uppper body strength is a must. I had heard horror stories about the surgery -- bad pain, improper healing. But I ccouldn't walk long distances and when I'd get caught off-balance, I'd tweek the foot in ways that hurt for days. I wanted to be able to get back in running shape and get my health in order for retirement. I am 55 and in good shape. I think the older and worser in shape you get, the more poorly you'll respond to the surgery. Try a good orthotic (SPENCO) -- see if it helps; maybe you can put off the surgery till later.
title: Any other guys deal with embarrasing feet problems....like bunions? corns?

title: Any other guys deal with embarrasing feet problems....like bunions? corns?

content: Toenail fungus problems are apparently the bane of the elderly. My mom's feet were a mess (she's 89). When we took her to a podiatrist, she refused to touch her (lazy POS). So I started cutting her toenails myself, and believe me, in the beginning, it was a sacrificial act of love. It's like clearing away dead wood from a tree so the live wood can grow. I had the bright idea of painting her toenails, thinking maybe it would smother the fungus. (Guess if a guy wanted to do that, he could use clear nail polish?) Anyway, it made them look better on a temporary basis, and made her feel better about herself. I've also started to really wash her feel well, with a very soapy washcloth. I am seeing a big improvement. She couldn't take the pills the docs gave her.

content: I've heard, applying Vicks at edge of the nail at the toe. Also apply it to the sides and base of the nail. I was using it, but forgot to use it! Applying Vicks to the nail wont don't any good as the nail is impervious to most anything! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
